reviewText: I love these old western series. I am so glad I bought this one. The stories are so interesting. I don't know how historically accurate they are but they are very entertaining. I wish there were more of them.

This television series from Republic Pictures is excellent and has many loved and familiar supporting actors. But there are problems with the DVD discs.  The picture sometimes freezes, or there is pixel separation. I have not been able to watch some titles because they will not play, or the player will skip over to the beginning of the nest title.  I have tried using another DVD player but the experience is the same with both. I returned the first copy I purchased and Amazon quickly sent me a new copy. But the problems continued with the new set. The series is good but the DVD product is defective, so I'd recommend waiting for another, better release if, or when, it becomes available.
Love this!  What a blast from the past.  Watched this program when young...loved it then love it now.

No closed caption and no subtitle! Don't buy DVD without subtitles. We are living in the era of disabilities discrimination during the Obama presidency. Liberal Democrats dislike disabilities, especially for powerless hearing impaired because they feel that we are weak, poor and brainless illiterate. We are deeply grateful to Republicans for establishing American Disability Act 1990 for giving our opportunities and advancements to all American disabilities which Democrats denied and ignored our disabilities plights and rights.

Stories Of The Century was an Historical western series highlighting many of the famous outlaws of the past with the aid of  stock footage from earlier Republic Pictures films. It aired for 2 seasons in 1954-55 starring Jim Davis. The following is the episode guide, highlighting the notable guest appearances. Fess Parker plays one of the Dalton brothers in episode 9, before he became famous as Davy Crockett.

Season 1

Ep 1  Belle Starr (Marie Windsor)
 Railroad Detective Matt Clark and his assistant Frankie Adams, investigate the stealing of a herd of horses belonging to the U. S. Cavalry. They learn that the leader of the outlaws is a woman named Belle Starr

Ep 2  Billy The Kid (Richard Jaekel)
Matt Clark, and his assistant Frankie Adams, set out on the trail of a gang of cattle rustlers led by one of the West's youngest and most notorious outlaws, Billy Bonney, aka Billy the Kid.

Ep 3  Frank And Jesse James  (Richard Travis, Lee Van Cleef)
Matt Clark and Frankie Adams  pursue the vengeful James brothers, Frank and Jesse, who declare war on the law after their young half-brother is killed in a police ambush

Ep 4  Geronimo (Chief Yowlachie, Emile Meyer)
Matt Clark and Frankie Adams, go after Apache chief Geronimo, who has been identified by Joe Burns, the night watchman of the railroad yards, as the leader of a band of freight-car robbers.

Ep 5  Quantrill And His Raiders  (Bruce Bennett, Lyle Talbot)
Matt and Frankie are asked by Colonel Marsham to infiltrate the vicious Quantrill gang. They do so on the eve of the Lawrence Kansas massacre that they are unable to prevent.

Ep 6  Cattle Kate  (Jean Parker)
Matt and Frankie head to Sweetwater, Wyoming where major cattle ranches are suffering heavy losses. A woman nicknamed Cattle Kate becomes the focus due the number of livestock she sells despite her small operation.

Ep 7  Sam Bass  (Don Haggerty, Denver Pyle)
After the Sam Bass gang steals sixty thousand dollar of gold coin from a train on which Frankie rides, Frankie pretends to be a waitress romantically interested in captured henchman Hayes to get Hayes to reveal Bass' location.

Ep 8  Johnny Ringo  (Donald Curtis)
Railroad detective Matt Clark learns of Johnny Ringo while investigating a train robbery. Frankie gets a job allowing her to some undercover work. Matt meets Johnny, a noted gunslinger, trailing him to a desert showdown

Ep 9  The Dalton Gang  (Fess Parker, Robert Bray)
Matt and Frankie head to Coffeyville in 1892 when they hear that the Dalton brothers and their gang are planning something big. They arrive in time to thwart the double bank robbery with the help of the stalwart citizens of the town

Ep 10  Doc Holliday  ( Kim Spalding)
Matt and Frankie head to Tombstone, Arizona to track down Doc Holliday who they suspect is involved with the Clanton gang. While there they meet famed sheriff Wyatt Earp and become part of the gunfight at OK Corral

Ep 11  The Younger Brothers (George Wallace, Gregory Walcott)
Matt and Frankie head to Tombstone, Arizona to track down Doc Holliday who they suspect is involved with the Clanton gang. While there they meet famed sheriff Wyatt Earp and become part of the gunfight at OK Corral

Ep 12  John Wesley Hardin  (Richard Webb)
John Wesley Hardin, the infamous killer, is herding cattle to Abilene when he shoots two Indians in cold blood. Detectives Matt and Frankie arrive in Kansas to bring him to justice. Hardin's time in prison, rehabilitation, and final gunfight are recounted

Ep 13  Joaquinn Murietta  ( Rick Jason)
The 1850's California gold fields is home to notorious bandit and killer Joaquin Murietta. Matt and Frankie arrive to track him down but he kidnaps Frankie, believing she owns his hacienda. Matt and Captain Love trail Murietta to the bitter end

Ep 14  Tiburcio Vasquez  (Anthony Caruso)
Tiburcio Vasquez vows vengeance against Anglos after his sister Dolores is killed. Matt and Frankie try to stop his years of terror in Southern California after a railroad agent is killed with the help of the local padre.

Ep 15  Chief Crazy Horse (George Keymas)

Ep 16  Black Bart  (Arthur Space)
Black Bart is responsible for a string of stage coach robberies but he has proved elusive to company detectives Matt and Frankie. Bob arrives from the city to help but it is the youngster Todd that provides the key to the case

Ep 17  Henry Plummer  (John Dehner, Lane Bradford)
Plummer is the sheriff of Bannock, Montana in the 1860's but runs a criminal gang as a source of wealth. When another stage is robbed Matt and Frankie arrive to find out who is behind the crime spree responsible for the deaths of so many

Ep 18  Bill Longley  (Douglas Kennedy)
After Longley and Kelso escape from a chain gang, Matt goes to a circus where Longley's girlfriend Mamie works while Kelso comes to get Mamie but mistakenly takes Frankie so that Longley must come himself and Matt follows to recover loot.

Ep 19  Harry Tracey  (Steve Brodie)
As the end of the 19th century, a murdering desperado Harry Tracy terrorizes America's northwest. Matt and Frankie head to the area after a train is stolen with Frankie going undercover. Soon Matt and a posse have the outlaw cornered.

Ep 20  The Wild Bunch Of Wyoming  ( Joe Sawyer, Slim Pickens)
Butch Cassidy is presented as a jovial type against killing as the leader of the notorious Wild Bunch. Matt and Frankie go after the outlaws when bank notes appear with phony signatures, trailing Butch all the way to South America

Ep 21  The Doolin Gang  (Leo Gordon)
After a robbery by the Doolin gang, Matt interviews a mortally wounded Ed Brinkley regarding the location of the Doolin hideout in Oklahoma. Frankie shows up pretending to be Ed's widow but the actual wife appears complicating matters. An ambush helps bring the Doolins to justice

Ep 22  Little Britches  (Gloria Winters, James Best)

Ep 23  Black Jack Ketcham  (Jack Elam)
Black Jack Ketchum is a wanted outlaw in two countries leading him to lie low at the Cullen Ranch in 1890's New Mexico. Matt and Frankie head to the area to stop the gang's activities and save young Eddie Cullen from a hangman's noose

Ep 24  Tom Horn  (Louis John Heydt)
Matt and Frankie stop in to see Matt's old friend Tom Horn while investigating a dispute involving cattle in Wyoming. When a young homesteader is killed the two detectives begin to see evidence adding up against Horn. Matt is shaken by his friend's betrayal

Ep 25  Ben Thompson  (Dick Simmons)
Matt and Frankie arrive in Austin in the 1880's to investigate the background of Ben Thompson. Matt gets employment at a gambling den owned by Ben's ex Texas where he starts to build a case establishing Ben's criminal activities

Ep 26  Clay Allison  (Jack Kelly)
During a robbery Frankie is shot as she pulls the mask off her assailant. Matt arrests John Allison, after Frankie's life is endangered when her doctor is kidnapped. An enraged Clay, known for his willingness to kill, falls into Matt's trap

Season 2

Ep 27  Burt Alvord  (Chris Drake)

Ep 28  Apache Kid  ( Kenneth Alton)
Matt and Margaret arrive at Fort Huachuca, Arizona to confer with Al Seiber in the murder of a ticket agent. They learn of an Indian Scout turned murderous and set off after him after he kidnaps a young woman, Tonia

Ep 29  Tom Bell  (Glen Gordon)
Tom Bell is a doctor in 1850's California going broke and loses his girl to a wealthier man. Bell becomes the first to try stagecoach robbing but murdering a railroad surveyor put Matt and Margaret on his trail. Justice arrives courtesy a betrayed woman.

Ep 30  Kate Bender (Veda Ann Borg, Slim Pickens)
Young Charles Ward has disappeared while traveling in Kansas leading detectives Matt and Margaret to discover why. The local sheriff reports others missing and they all stayed with Kate Bender. An investigation leads to a grim discovery and deadly justice for the Benders.

Ep 31  Augustine Chacon  (Rodolfo Hoyos Jr)
Augustine Chacon is an infamous badman responsible for numerous deaths on both sides of the border. The murders of two Texas Rangers bring Matt and Margaret into Mexico where they trail Chacon's girlfriend Felicia to achieve their goal.

Ep 32  Cherokee Bill  (Pat Hogan)
After Cherokee Bill murders a marshall aboard a train, railroad detectives Matt Clark and Margaret Jones are called in. They capture him after tracking him to Mrs. Lynch's cabin, his mother. But another escape leads to a showdown between a ruthless gang and the law.

Ep 33  Nate Champion  (Henry Brandon)

Ep 34  Sontag And Evans  (John Smith, Morris Ankrum)
Chris Evans and John Sontag have separate grudges against the railroads leading them to team up for train robberies in the 1890's. Matt and Margaret head to central California to bring them to justice using Evan's niece.

Ep 35  Rube Burrows  (Paul Picerni)
Alabama born Rube Burrows becomes infamous through the south for train robbery in the late 1880's but his girlfriend Emma is portrayed as the brains. Margaret ingratiates herself with the outlaws leading to a deadly showdown.

Ep 36  Jim Courtright  (Robert Knapp)
Jim Courtright, a former sheriff, runs a protection racket in 1880's Texas and takes drastic measures when men refuse to pay. Matt and Margaret arrive after a railroad man is killed. Saloon owner Luke Short decides to stand up to Courtright.

Ep 37  Milt Sharp  (Don Barry)
Matt and Margaret investigate the kidnapping of banker Penrose from a stagecoach. They immediately suspect noted bandit Milt Sharp who recently escaped from a Nevada prison and his partner Dutch. A showdown takes place at the Penrose home where maid Sarah is a important factor.

Ep 38  Jack Slade  (Gregg Palmer)

Ep 39  L H Musgrove  (John Archer)
Matt and Margaret head to Denver in the late 1860's after the killing of a railroad telegraph operator. Bail jumper L H Musgrove, a known horse thief is their chief suspect. Musgrove and his pal end up facing vigilante justice.

The Hollywood B or series western came to a sudden end in the early 1950s when kids abandoned the Saturday matinee to watch similar fare on Saturday morning TV.  Major western stars Roy Rogers, Gene Autry, Hopalong Cassidy, The Lone Ranger and The Cisco Kid immediately jumped into television and were joined by Range Rider, Cowboy G-Men, Kit Carson, Jim Bowie, Annie Oakley and dozens of others.

Perhaps the best directed, best written and most exciting of all was STORIES OF THE CENTURY that ran for one 39-episode season in 1939, produced by Republic Pictures. Veteran William Witney, who directed the best Republic serials from 1937 on (The Lone Ranger, Captain Marvel, Spy Smasher) and the best Roy Rogers color westerns of the late 1940s, helmed the first 30 episodes of CENTURY. Witney was adept at staging non-stop fights and chases and seamlessly integrated them with the Republic stock library of stampedes, indian attacks and building explosions used as serial endings.

The hero is railroad detective Matt Clark, played by burly, no-nonsense Jim Davis. Each week Matt tangles with a famous western outlaw - Jesse James (Lee Van Cleef), Billy the Kid, Belle Starr (Marie Windsor) and Geronimo in just the first four episodes! After the whirlwind action involving Matt, the true demises of the bad guys are enacted taken from actual newspaper accounts of the times.

Matt Clark is ably assisted in each adventure by a woman detective who matches him in fist fights and gun play. Mary Castle, who somewhat resembles Rita Hayworth, plays Frankie in the first 26 episodes, and Kristine Miller plays Jonesy in 14. The ladies usually go undercover as a post mistress, piano player or shop girl, but just as quickly jump into the action. Off screen romancing with Matt is implied.

STORIES OF THE CENTURY is available complete for the first time in this box set of all 39 episodes put out by Nostalgia Family. Quality is excellent. Highly recommended.
Great series.  It's fun seeing the young Jim Davis.  Am very glad I purchased this DVD set.

This not the first release of Stories of the Century. The series has been in the public domain for many years and as such, several PD companies have put out compilations of various episodes,, mostly from battered & choppy old TV prints. To my knowlege though ,this is the first time all 39 episodes have been put out as a complete set..The episodes are spread over 5 discs, so not over compressed, on a single spindle in a standard sized amray case. There are no extras.

The series itself dates from the early 50's & was made by Hollywood Television Services which was the TV arm of Republic Studios, famous for all their 'B' westerns. It stars Jim Davis as railroad detective Matt Clark, an entirely fictional character tracking down just about every real life outlaw from the old west., some famous such as Billy the Kid, Jesse James & Black Bart , along with some lesser known characters. Curiously his undercover 'sidekick' for this series was a woman Frankie Adams ,played by Mary Castle. . Frankie was not the usual shrinking violet type of lead common in westerns of the period but actually involved herself in the action. She was replaced later in the series by another woman 'Jonesy' played by Kristine Miller.

Despite the historical inaccuracies the series is entertaing & enhanced by armloads of stock footage from Republic's library. Seasoned fans of old westerns will also spot many regular western players such as Lee Van Cleef & others in early roles.

However, the main reason for obtaining this set over others out there is the quality. Surprisingly someone has gone to the trouble & expense of remastering the prints & they are presented here in clean ,sharp quality, 100% better than anything released before
